Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Selective constraints, genetic correlations, and divergence of the flavonoid pathway in Silene vulgaris
Award.AbstractNarration:
The plant flavonoid pathway forms distinct groups of chemicals responsible for several important roles, including pigmentation, plant defense, antioxidants, and sunscreen. An interconnected network of genes is responsible for the production of each flavonoid subgroup. Changes in gene regulation and subsequent flavonoid expression will be controlled by genes and enzymes that are shared among different branches of the pathway, suggesting that there may be trade-offs between flavonoid groups and therefore the related ecological functions. Next-generation sequencing in the form of multiple transcriptomes will be made of Silene vulgaris individuals taken from a reciprocal transplant experiment of high and low elevation plants (high and low UV-B environments) to test for adaptation to specific environments and flavonoid gene expression, which will be compared to chemical analyses of flavonoids. This will allow the consideration the entire flavonoid pathway simultaneously, in particular how increased expression of a specific branch affects the overall expression phenotype.
Studying the correlated traits of a metabolic pathway will shed light on the evolution of secondary metabolism in plants, illuminating how different points in gene networks can be subject to adaptive evolution and influence overall pathway development. Since flavonoids are ubiquitous, this research will be applicable to most plants. In particular, the proposed research will also expand on knowledge of plant adaptive divergence along UV-B gradients, shifts in which have been associated with human-mediated global change. This proposal also details using next-generation sequencing techniques in a natural setting and non-model organism, which may encourage further studies along those lines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plant flavonoid pathway is instrumental in the response to the environment in the form of phenotypic plasticity and in adaptation. One such group of flavonoids, called the flavones, can act as anti-feedants for herbivores, antifungals, and also as sunscreens. The anthocyanins, another important flavonoid group, are responsible for floral color (reds, blues, purples), as well as in thermoregulation. We studied the gene expression of the flavonoid pathway in the widespread plant, Silene vulgaris (Caryophyllaceae), while manipulating elevation. Flavones and anthocyanins are the only flavonoid groups present in adult S. vulgaris individuals (Berardi et al. in prep).

Comparisons between high and low elevation environments provide broad differences in several important factors affecting plant life, such as temperature, moisture, light, and biotic interactions. We identified flavonoid pathway genes in S. vulgaris that would be directly involved in the response to the environment through plasticity (being able to change phenotype as a response to an environmental stimulation) or adaptation, and tested their expression in leaf and floral tissue using a reciprocal transplant RNAseq study with high and low elevation plants reciprocally planted at high and low elevation gardens. Flavonoid pathway gene expression was found to be both responsive to the environment on a per-locus basis, as well as having genotypic similarities with populations of the same elevation origin performing similarly. We found more flavonoid gene expression in floral tissue compared to leaf tissue in both experimental gardens. We also found similar expression of FS (flavone synthase) in leaves and flowers by populations of the same elevation origin, with low elevation of origin populations expressing higher amounts of FS at both experimental gardens, suggesting that adaptation to flavone expression has occurred at different elevations. Network analysis showed modularity in flavonoid pathway expression, with the terminal branch genes showing more variability of expression across environments.

We also measured flavonoid-related phenotypes in the experimental gardens that correlate with flavonoid gene expression: floral color and flavone concentration. Generally speaking, anthocyanin concentration in the flowers was greater at the high elevation garden - likely contributing to our observation of increased gene expression in the flowers compared to the leaves in the case of high elevation garden individuals. More flavonoid structural gene expression is required for anthocyanin production than flavone production. Genotypes originating from high elevations also had more floral anthocyanins than did the low elevation plants. Correlating with our FS gene observations, the number of different types of flavones increased in the low elevation origin plants at the high elevation. We also found that flavone concentration increased in leaves at the high elevation.

In summary, we found variability in flavonoid gene expression by genotype and by elevation, suggesting that Silene vulgaris used the flavonoid pathway in its adaptation to high elevation environments. Higher levels of flavonoid gene expression and flavonoid concentration were found at the high elevation garden. Flowers were more darkly pigmented at the high elevation garden, suggesting different requirements for temperature regulation and pollinator attraction. Plants from low elevations expressed higher levels of flavone synthase. We suspect this is due to the higher exposure to UV radiation and the need for more sun-screening, whereas in their native populations they may not be as exposed to UV radiation.
